The Remembered, A Global Study of Literature Dissertations' Bibliography

XML

My doctoral project aims to build a map of contemporary literary research through the application of reference mining methods in a multinational corpus of ca. 3,000 electronic doctoral dissertations (ETDs) from Literature Departments in Argentina, Chile, Germany, the United States and Mexico (2000-2020). In the following lines I will explain why ETDs are a necessary source for understanding the history of this academic field but also how reference mining can build cartography of the “remembered” and unveil the untraveled regions of the literary “Mnemosyne”.

First, it should be acknowledged that dissertations are the default “rite of passage” through which students become researchers. That is, they are the almost inescapable ritual through which a former student enters the academic sphere. Secondly, doctoral research typically passes through several phases of approval by an institutional community: the proposal acceptance, the internal upgrade/review, and the external panel or examination. Thus, they are a good compass of what different regions and institutions consider “satisfactory knowledge” to become an academic.

Thirdly, other than briefer genres of academic writing such as journal articles, dissertations tend to require at least more than 3 years. While it is recommended that the completion of the research investigation should be done within 3 years, with submission no more than 1 year later (Wright and Cochrane, 2000) studies in the sociology of science have shown that more time is often needed to undertake research required for humanities and social sciences’ dissertations (Becher and Trowler, 2001; Parry, 2007). For instance, in Norway “59% of the PhD candidates in the natural sciences had graduated with a PhD within [4] years, in contrast to 38% in the humanities and 28% in the social sciences” (Kyvik and Olsen, 2014). Hence, it is safe to say that 3,000 Literature ETDs are at least 12,000 years of human research in the field.

Citation Analysis (CA) is the area of bibliometrics that studies the relationship between a cited and a citing document, and it has been increasingly used to “study, map, and evaluate academic research” (Hammarfelt, 2012). The basic input for CA is a citation database and Reference Mining (RM), a “Natural Language Processing (NLP) task focused on the detection, extraction and classification of bibliographic references and their constituent components” (Rodrigues Alves et al., 2018), has been a useful computational method to obtain this information as data.

In order to delineate the known (but uncharted) borders of the “remembered”, and the roads citations have unknowingly built I have proposed to investigate a mostly ignored data source: the millions of references buried in doctoral thesis. My hypothesis is that by paying attention to the citation patterns in a multinational and multilingual corpus of literary dissertations, it is possible to reveal patterns of literary research in at least three dimensions: national and institutional trends in a global context; interdisciplinary and intercultural connections; and genre defined behaviors. With this in mind, this research proposes to answer the following questions:

1. What are the national and/or institutional trends of the “remembered” in European and Latin American dissertations? (i.e. who are the most cited authors in Germany, and how are they different or similar from those cited in other parts of the world?)

2. How intercultural are these approaches? How often is Jorge Luis Borges cited along his German influences: Hölderlin, Silesius, Goethe?

3. Is it true that multidisciplinary approaches are becoming more popular and if so, what are their characteristics? For example, do medieval studies have a canon that includes publications from different sciences?

4. Is it possible to create topology of the citation networks of different genres and subgenres? For instance, which patterns of co-citation emerge in feminist dystopian fiction?

Answering these questions might be crucial for two main reasons. Firstly, because while research has strongly suggested that cultural barriers and traditional disciplinary systems are major hindrances for interdisciplinary research (Holm et al., 2013; Mauser et al., 2013), little research has been done to quantitatively draw institutional and national traditions. Having a map of these traditions or literary “Mnemosyne” will help bridge communication between groups from different institutions, countries and disciplines. Secondly, because the humanities in general, and literary studies in particular, have been going through what many have considered a crisis (Batubenge, 2016; Marcovitch, 2002; Nussbaum, 2010) and we need to understand our travelled world, in order to rethink our routes, revisit our roads, and draw new highways.

Appendix A

Bibliography

  2. Becher, T. and Trowler, P. (2001). Academic Tribes and Territories . McGraw-Hill Education (UK).
  3. Hammarfelt, B. (2012). Harvesting footnotes in a rural field: Citation patterns in Swedish literary studies. Journal of Documentation , 68 (4): 536–58.
  4. Holm, P., Goodsite, M. E., Cloetingh, S., Agnoletti, M., Moldan, B., Lang, D. J., Leemans, R., et al. (2013). Collaboration between the natural, social and human sciences in Global Change Research. Environmental Science & Policy , 28 . (Special Issue: Responding to the Challenges of Our Unstable Earth (RESCUE)): 25–35 doi:10.1016/j.envsci.2012.11.010.
  5. Kyvik, S. and Olsen, T. B. (2014). Increasing completion rates in Norwegian doctoral training: multiple causes for efficiency improvements. Studies in Higher Education , 39 (9). Routledge: 1668–82 doi:10.1080/03075079.2013.801427.
  6. Marcovitch, J. (2002). Os desafios da área de Humanidades no Brasil e no mundo. Estudos Avançados , 16 (46): 223–43 doi:10.1590/S0103-40142002000300017.

Current Opinion in Environmental Sustainability , 5 (3). (Open Issue): 420–31 doi:10.1016/j.cosust.2013.07.001.
  8. Nussbaum, M. C. (2010). Not for Profit: Why Democracy Needs the Humanities . (Ed.) Princeton University Press Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press.
  9. Parry, S. (2007). Disciplines and Doctorates . Vol. 16. Springer.
